"The symbol is to be placed on the device housing the source, as a warning not to dismantle the device or to get any closer. It will not be visible under normal use, only if someone attempts to disassemble the device."

I know. But your post still made me realize that the real problem isn't the design of the symbol, it's that too many people don't recognize the symbol.

Putting something aside from a dot in the middle helps with that i think. the arcs look more radiant and lest abstract. Perhaps it needs a real reworking rather then the patch on a patch on a patch on a triangle that the PR offers.

The problem with depicting a warning for ionizing radiation is that you can't really sense it apart from being a little bit warm. How does one illustrate an invisible fire that will make you sterile and give you cancer and make your hair and teeth fall out in some days to weeks' time? How does one even imagine such an image? Abstract symbols pulled out of one's arse seem to be the only recourse, and with those you need a massive public education campaign, and we're back to where we started.

Yes, large sources can get a very very hot. That's how nuclear power plants work, but if you're close enough to feel it that much you're pretty well cooked already.

_How does one illustrate an invisible fire that will make you sterile and give you cancer and make your hair and teeth fall out in some days to weeks’ time? How does one even imagine such an image?_

Photos of Tammy Faye Baker w/o the paint? Give the right idea instinctively.

I just think that a mod of the existing symbol is the right idea. It puts to use the fortune already spent on education. With as many people as there are already aware of it, it isn't worthless. But it isn't stellar, as it is too abstract, and only seems to be chosen because it look like it belongs with similar symbols (biohaz./fallout shelter). There are a lot of ideas that might work better. Flames made of dotted lines? A diseased, shedding cat? Mr. Yuck with x's for eyes? Mr. Yuck is great, from a universal stand point, I imagine.

I suspect a team of professionals could come up with something both abstract and pertinent.

The other problem, I think is that the Rad symbol has been overused, decreasing it's alarm. Since people see it where there is indeed radiation, but they are very unlikely to suffer adverse affects (normally), they disregard the mediocre symbol. Which is why the IAEA wants the new symbol to mean, "dangerous, no really this time"; we broke the last one.

My 2 cents... Is it ugly? Yes, of course. From a design standpoint it is definitely not appealing. But according to their description, it has been tested in 11 countries, and the message was clearly understood. So ultimately - it is a success. Regardless of whether it appeals to our aesthetic sensibilities. This is a prime example of how something "ugly" can still work. I have to admit I have seen bad design, that fails miserably according to all the principles of good design, but somehow still seems to communicate.
